review_title: Poor Management, Heavy Workload, Great People
job_title: Care Navigator in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Loved the staff and my coworkers/ inpatient and outpatient team, supportive teammates. Nursing staff was helpful for the most part as well as the doctors. Benefits were good, 401K option available with 3 year vetting. Advocated and got weekly supervision with an LCSW. Got a good amount of training for my role understanding that you can never be fully trained on all possible situations you will encounter.
cons: Heavy caseload of 17 patients for discharged planning which can be difficulty when discharges are anticipates, new patients on the floor who are discharging, meeting and rounds. Manager was helpful but when she left aft approximately 10months, director stepped in and barely helped inpatient staff. Social workers paid less than nurses despite needing a masters degree and nurses requiring a bachelors. Was told the nurses were more educated even though expectation of work was THE SAME. Poor advocacy from management for care navigators as they do not get paid holidays. Useless weekly length of stay meeting to discuss how to improve the length of time patients stay in the hospital, mind you this does not include physicians who determine when a patient can discharge, makes sense to management who has never spent a day discharge planning.

cons: They take PTO on holidays off, no bonus or major salary increase

review_title: Family-Feel community, but many challenges. Great potential for growth.
job_title: ICU Registered Nurse in Silver Spring, MD
pros:
-Family-feel community, feel supported by my peers
-Adaptable scheduling
-Opportunities for education and experience. Lots of opportunity for training.
cons:
-Too many demands, too little compensation--staff members are leaving due to lack of financial incentives.
-Charting system is inefficient, often duplicate charting, waste time charting instead of caring for patients; new requirements for charting almost every other week.
-Constant logistical challenges--ie, poor communication (have to call pharmacy, phlebotomy, materials, dietary MULTIPLE times in order to receive what you need)
-Throughput is either too slow or way too fast, no consistency.
-Many doctors fail to write orders or don't correctly input orders, requiring the nursing staff to fix order sets. 
-Confusion over which provider is caring for patient, especially for cardiac surgery patients (no clarity over whom to call for orders). 
-Only ONE charge nurse for ICU is not sufficient for support needed. 
-Not enough staff support: staff are floated to other units, yet often no resource staff is available to aid in patient care or to land crashing patients. At best, we'll have one PCT; usually, no PCT available. Occasional tripling of patient assignments occurs at nights, as well (fortunately, less common during day shift).
-Excessive micromanagement; almost-constant audits. 
-Staff communication device, Vocera, is full of bugs and has poor voice recognition. Requires repetition of names and requests.

review_title: Managers suck Administration supports it, toxic work environment
job_title: Mental Health Worker in Rockville, MD
pros: Some people are helped and supported in their treatment for mental illnesses.
cons: The Behavior Health Building is unfortunately a dismal place. People have died, some units are subpar and dirty. Patients are locked in for days or weeks at a time. Staff pay is so variable and not always based on skills but who you know. Which is an insult to those who really did the work. Tx of staff is dismal at best. However, these groups give accolades Baldrige, WP...while the staff are flocking out the door.

I used to think I knew my stuff, but I have never been treated more like dirt.

job_title: Team Leader in White Oak, MD
pros: Great Benefits, even offers insurance for your pets. Beautiful new facility not far from the highway. Easy free covered parking. The grounds are absolutely stunning. Competitive salary amongst healthcare industry which says a lot because I have worked within some of the most renowned hospitals.
cons: Biased management, preferential treatment of certain employees. Job expectations and hours of employment changed multiple times without notice. Employees that were supposed to be equal as in job titles were not treated as such. One lead person was the ring leader that never worked unless management was present to occasionally crack the whip. This team lead spent all day “making copies”, yet was prized as an exemplary lead. I have never worked for an organization where the leads are missing for numerous unaccounted for hours, leaving the new employees to figure things out on their own.

job_title: Chief Radiation Therapist in Takoma Park, MD
pros: This is a family oriented organization
cons: None to report for now

pros: It's a paycheck, I need the money, and it's close to home.
cons: I have been the healthcare field for a little over 10yrs and I am CRCS- I.  This is the only institution where the workers have more knowledge then our leaders; in other words its who you know not what you know.  You must be quite, have know educated opinions of your own, and do as I say attitude from management.  Other there is another financial management company that stepped in for the greater good of overseeing finances for our hospital; but what about the poor unqualified managers let alone them knowing what AAHAM is. I'm currently looking for better employment to feel secure about my job and not be scared concerning my job.  They have terminated great workers because of their poor management skills and I don't want to be employed by Adventist Healthcare anymore because of this. Their mission is for the patients, but not for their loyal employers

pros:
Co-workers are great and really care about the patients and each other.

Health insurance is affordable and pretty comprehensive if you go to Adventist approved facilities & providers.
cons:
Mid-level managers are afraid to admit there are problems in their departments due to fear that upper management will fire employees/them as a "FIX" to the problem.  As a result, nothing gets "fixed" until it becomes a crisis.

I found out when I left there that they do not participate in COBRA due to a religious organization exemption.  It took me a month to apply and get accepted for Obamacare, without that, I'd be declined for insurance due to multiple pre-existing conditions.

Upper management changes frequently so it is difficult to have similar priorities from one management group to another.

review_title: 2014: AHC Transitions to a New CEO - Terry Forde
pros: A faith based organization that employs an incredibly diverse staff. The new CEO, Terry Forde, understands there is a healthy balance in delivering outstanding care to patients, providing support to employees and collaborating with physicians. He is interested in innovation and creativity - a breath of fresh air in healthcare today. Executive leadership has and will continue to commit to developing its leaders. Also proactive in offering healthy living resources/services to all employees.
cons: Frontline staff and middle managers stretched further each quarter continually having to do more and more with less. It may take awhile for the new CEOs philosophies, thinking and practices to trickle down. Compensation tends to below competitors yet other benefits may fill the need for some employees.

review_title: Lost touch of how to value its employees.
pros: It is a faith based organization (although lately you wouldn't know it by how it's executives are treating their employees), and there are awesome people there who can become friends for life.
cons: The cons really came in within the last few years, many people are insecure about whether they will have a job next week. This added stress and the corporate politics have left employees feeling under-valued.

review_title: Good organization & values, Management needs improvement
pros:
Most of the people who work there are kind, helpful and considerate. The facility itself is well-maintained and the organization tries to promote a culture of health and wellness without being too pushy.
Their benefits are pretty good (almost free at any adventist facility) and they offer subsidized food at the cafeteria (with an additional discount for employees). They often have promotions for fitbits and other gadgets.
cons:
Depending on who your Nurse Manager is, you will either get treated well or poorly. Scheduling can be haphazard and asking for a day off is almost like committing a sin!
As a psychiatric technician, you will not actually be doing any "psychiatric" work. Your day will basically revolve around escorting patients for food and keeping a check on them.

review_title: Behavioral Health Units: Good floor staff, poor management
pros: Jovial and fun floor staff, some units have almost a familial environment.  unit managers are generally good but highly overworked
cons: Extraordinarily poor staffing measures.  Units are constantly full yet chronically understaffed.  complaints are made regularly but the upper level management does not seem to listen. Managers rarely stay on for more than a year due to the stress of the environment. Because of the emphasis on filling beds, patients are often placed on inappropriate units to the detriment of staff and patient safety.

job_title: Administrative Coordinator in Takoma Park, MD
pros: Coworkers are very warm and willing to help. They encourage and appreciate the work that you do. The executives are pretty involved in the day-to-day operations. This hospital serves low income, uninsured population. If you like to work in a hospital-setting knowing that you are truly helping the mos undeserved, then this is the right place for you.  The pay is competitive but hard to grow in this company given the lack of resources.
cons: The facilities are really old and need a lot of improvement. Resources are very limited in terms of capital and human resources but then again that would prove true to any safety-net type of organization. The traffic is heavy at most times of the day and the parking situation for employees is  chaotic.

review_title: Very tough to succeed here, hard work is satisfying but administration is not supportive of line staff and poor benefits
pros: Great team members, fast paced. Good place for new grads to learn and take experience with you to an organization that will value it.
cons: Low salary ranges, far below average in this area, health benefits are not good, very little vacation time and no paid holidays, managment makes it tough to use your leave time because of under staffed.

review_title: Not a great place to learn new skills and be challenged at work
pros: Good work life balance (probably due to the cons, discussed at length below) and decent health care benefits.
cons: EXTREMELY stagnant, slow-paced environment. Numerous employees at the Support Center location across several functions did not have enough work to fill even a 25-hour work week. Managers also seemed to do day-to-day tasks that should be delegated to their subordinates, and be completely unaware of how to engage their employees.

review_title: Zero accountability for Directors and VPs
pros: Time off policy, flexibility with work, Informal work environment
cons: Zero accountability, Unfair and incompetent Directors and VPs. Top heavy. Directors and VPs get bonuses and pay hikes while staff are left with nothing. There are several highly incompetent and unqualified directors that are hampering staff from doing good work due to their own insecurities and lack of skills. This creates a rather difficult work environment if you are a top performer.

pros: Only the close proximity to folks living in Rockville or Gaithersburg.
cons:
Benefits are not good
No work-life balance
Poor and dumb management
Fear and threats are often used by management

pros: I really enjoyed working with my co-workers.Most of them genuinely cared about the pts.
cons: The administration said they had one set of standards, but operated by another. I stopped an 11 yr old pt from harming himself, rather than watch him do it as another employee did and guess which one of us still has a job.

review_title: Good company to start at and learn
pros: There is plenty of opportunity for ambitious individuals to get involved in improving business processes. There some really good supportive people you will work with. There a lot of Adventist institutions that this employer can prime you for.
cons: Management is stagnant, and relatively noncompetitive for keeping top talent. There seems to be a culture of mediocrity that allow some people to resent those that strive for excellence. Some of the process improvement changes are met with fierce resistance.

pros: Great place every to work. Ability to grow and expand your skills sets while  learning new skills sets. Great benefits
cons: In order to build the new hospital in Silver Spring  the  company has layer off mid to upper mid-level management staff. This the level where their expertise is. This has caused some instability in may areas of operations.

review_title: Good people, company with limited willingness to invest in its employees or innovations.
pros: It's great to work for a faith-based nonprofit where the mission matters and people really care about each other
cons: Way behind its competitors in patient care innovations and investments in workplace satisfaction, professional development etc. Also often management is too "nice" to fire incompetent employees.

pros: 80% of the people you will work with here, are the reason you come to work. That and the front line hospital workers if you ever  are on the receiving end of their care.
cons:
The other 20% of the people, the extreme amount of politics, and lack of organizational structure make a hostile and vapid environment.

I have seen many that take responsibility and have great work ethic be passed up on the scarce occasion there is a promotions.  They are usually handed to individuals who have the right persons ear.

review_title: Great Employees, Good Executives and Strong, Developing Leaders
pros: Many teams collaborate well together and support each other individually. Employees stay with AHC because of their team members. Good benefits package.
cons: Unskilled leaders and physicians with little emotional intelligence are retained even though their behavior contributes to turnover costs and poor employee engagement.  Work/life balance is improving yet still opportunity to address this as it's key to healthcare workers' health/well-being.

review_title: Could be a great place to work but has very poor leadership
pros: Flexible work schedule, very good benefits, great leave policy and wonderful people to work with.
cons: Poor financial perfomance, poor managment, ill-equipped leaders, absolutely no technology of any kind.  I am surprised we are not still using stone tablets.  They have great people but do nothing to nuture them.

review_title: Would not recommend this place to anyone.
job_title: Office Supervisor in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Meeting, networking, and creating relationships with great providers and staff
cons: all about money and not healthcare...very disappointing

pros: Some of the managers are genuinely nice people, but they are vastly outnumbered by the incompetent ones
cons: Very technologically old fashioned in business practices. Management does a ton of talking but no doing. I had zero work/life balance- I would get called on my days off and I regretted every sick day I took.

pros: I am a new employee with Adventist. Every one is so nice! The organization  believes in Internal growth definitely a plus. You see leadership on a daily basis walking around offering words of encouragement, and interested in how your day is going- priceless!
cons: I can not think of anything. Every thing is wonderful so far. Learning a lot.
